docs.lead_paragraph: There is an important conflict to resolve in the federal circuit courts about the labeling requirement on cigarette packages. The law should be upheld.
docs.abstract: Editorial criticizes United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia for striking down 2009 law forcing tobacco companies to put large, graphic health warnings on their products; argues there is strong evidence that warnings are effective countermeasure to deceptive tobacco advertising; calls on government to seek review of ruling.
docs.snippet: There is an important conflict to resolve in the federal circuit courts about the labeling requirement on cigarette packages. The law should be upheld.

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI - Accepting a just-picked mango from a stranger in Lodi Gardens and then putting it directly into my mouth - skin and all - was stupid. I admit that. But why did my first horrible case of traveler's diarrhea in India have to result from a mango? I love mangoes, and India's vast array of deliciously different mango varieties has been one of the great delights of moving here.
docs.snippet: NEW DELHI - Accepting a just-picked mango from a stranger in Lodi Gardens and then putting it directly into my mouth - skin and all - was stupid. I admit that.   But why did my first horrible case of   traveler's diarrhea  in India have to result...

docs.abstract: Despite decades of immunological research and a recent surge of interest in the bacterial garden of the human gut, diarrhea remains the most unpredictable travel-related illness.
docs.snippet: Despite decades of immunological research and a recent surge of interest in the bacterial garden of the human gut, diarrhea remains the most unpredictable travel-related illness.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Beasley discovered that the virus is easily transferred from mothers to infants during childbirth, and confirmed its role in causing liver cancer.

headline.seo: R. Palmer Beasley, Hepatitis B Researcher, Dies at 76
headline.main: R. Palmer Beasley, Expert on Hepatitis B, Dies at 76
headline.print_headline: R. Palmer Beasley, Expert On Hepatitis B, Dies at 76

docs.abstract: Dr R Palmer Beasley, epidemiologist who was an expert on Hepatitis B, dies at age 76.
docs.snippet: Dr. Beasley discovered that the virus is easily transferred from mothers to infants during childbirth, and confirmed its role in causing liver cancer.

docs.lead_paragraph: Much genetic research is predicated on study subjects being anonymous, but increasingly researchers are discovering things these subjects, or their relatives, might need or like to know.

headline.seo: With Rise of Gene Sequencing, Ethical Puzzles
headline.main: Genes Now Tell Doctors Secrets They Can’t Utter
headline.print_headline: Genes Now Tell Doctors Secrets They Can’t Utter

docs.abstract: Much genetic research is predicated on study subjects being anonymous, but increasingly researchers are discovering things these subjects, or their relatives, might need or like to know; question of how, when and whether to return genetic results to study subjects or their families is a particularly thorny challenge in clinical research, and one wrought with both practical and ethical complications.
docs.snippet: Much genetic research is predicated on study subjects being anonymous, but increasingly researchers are discovering things these subjects, or their relatives, might need or like to know.

docs.lead_paragraph: Future doctors will need to correct the postmodern tendency toward immune dysregulation.

headline.main: An Immune Disorder at the Root of Autism
headline.print_headline: An Immune Disorder at the Root of Autism

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by author Moises Velasquez-Manoff notes current research suggesting that a subset of autism may be caused by an inflammatory disease in the womb; concludes work toward correcting maternal immune dysregulation may contribute to the prevention of autism.
docs.snippet: Future doctors will need to correct the postmodern tendency toward immune dysregulation.

docs.lead_paragraph: ESTES--Dr. Dorothy, distinguished physician and rheumatologist, died on August 21, 2012 in New York City after a long illness. Dr. Estes practiced at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center through most of her career. Her practice focused on diseases of connective tissue such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus erythematosus, in which she made major contributions to the immunological understanding and advances in therapy. She was a highly regarded teacher of medicine at the Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons, where she was a Clinical Professor. In addition to her practice and teaching, she served in many other positions at the Columbia Medical Center, as Director of the Rheumatology Laboratory (1979-1990), Chairman of the Affirmative Action Committee of the Health Sciences Division of Columbia University (1974 - 1993). She was the first woman President of Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons Alumni Association (75-77). She was born in Brooklyn, the daughter of Clementine and Thomas Willingham Estes. She attended the Low-Heyward school in Stamford Connecticut and then attended Wheaton College, class of 1946, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She obtained her medical degree from Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons in 1950. She was awarded the Alumni Federation of Columbia University Medal in 1975 and the Silver Medal of the P&S alumni association. In 1999 she was awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award of the New York Chapter of the Arthritis Foundation. She was a member of the Board of Directors of the American Bureau for Medical Advancement in China (ABMAC), where she instituted a Student Exchange Program for medical students in Taiwan to study in New York. She was a Visiting Professor at the Peking Union Medical College, Beijing, China in 1994. She was married to Dr. Gerard M. Turino, also a Professor of medicine at Columbia, for over 60 years. She is survived by her husband, three sons, Peter, Phillip and James, their spouses, Julie and Sherri, four grandchildren, Caroline, Christopher, Frances and Harrison, and her sister, Emily Whalen. Dottie was a warm and loving mother and wife. She will live on in our memories. Friends may call on Friday August 24, 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Service Monday August 27, 10:30am at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave. at 71st St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Dorothy Estes Scholarship Fund at Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons, 630 West 168th St., NY, NY 10032.
